questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is associated with celiac disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Anti-TTG

questions.text: Hepcidin acts on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Site of Iron Transfer

Mechanism of Iron Transfer

Intestine

Absorption of dietary iron occurs mainly in the duodenum and upper jejunum. Iron is transported across the enterocytes by the divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) and released into the bloodstream via ferroportin.

Bloodstream

Iron is bound to transferrin, a protein that transports iron in the blood. Transferrin-bound iron is delivered to cells expressing transferrin receptors through receptor-mediated endocytosis. Iron is released from transferrin in the acidic environment of the endosome and transported into the cytoplasm by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

Macrophages

Macrophages phagocytose senescent red blood cells and recycle the iron from hemoglobin. Inside macrophages, hemoglobin is degraded into heme and globin. Heme oxygenase breaks down heme into biliverdin, releasing iron. Iron is stored within the macrophages as ferritin or transported out of the cells via ferroportin and delivered to the bloodstream for utilization.

Liver

Hepatocytes take up iron from the bloodstream via transferrin receptor-mediated endocytosis. Inside hepatocytes, iron is stored in ferritin or used for the synthesis of iron-containing proteins, such as heme and iron-sulfur clusters. Excess iron can be exported out of hepatocytes through ferroportin and released into the bloodstream or stored in ferritin.

Bone Marrow

Iron is necessary for erythropoiesis, the production of red blood cells. In the bone marrow, iron is taken up by developing erythroblasts through transferrin receptor-mediated endocytosis. Iron is utilized for the synthesis of heme, which is incorporated into hemoglobin.

Placenta

During pregnancy, iron is transferred from the mother to the fetus through the placenta. Transferrin receptors on the placental syncytiotrophoblasts bind to maternal transferrin, and iron is transported across the syncytiotrophoblasts and released into the fetal circulation for fetal development.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. A duodenal biopsy shows crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in the lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Celiac disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

Synonym
  • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
  • Celiac sprue

Diagnosis

  • Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum

Serum markers
  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-most sensitive
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)-most specific

Histology
  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis),
  • Crypt hyperplasia (increased mitosis)
  • Villous atrophy (reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption)
  • Inflammatory cells infiltration

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is correct? An arborizing pattern of smooth muscle Loss of heterozygosity in STK11 gene Multiple GI polyps Autosomal recessive inheritance Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigmental epithelium is seen
The cells lining the isthmus of gastric pits are:
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Location

Function

Stem cells

Isthmus of gastric pits

Regenerate the various types of gastric epithelial cells.

Parietal cells

Fundus and body of the stomach

It secretes hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factors that are important for digestion and vitamin B12 absorption.

Chief cells

Fundus and body of the stomach

Secrete pepsinogen, which is converted to pepsin in the acidic environment, to aid in protein digestion.

Mucous cells

Surface epithelium of the stomach lining and neck of gastric pits

Secrete mucus to protect the stomach lining from the acidic environment and digestive enzymes.

Endocrine cells (G cells)

Antrum of the stomach

Secrete gastrin, which stimulates acid secretion by parietal cells and gastric motility.

Enteroendocrine cells

Throughout the gastric mucosa

Secrete various hormones such as somatostatin, serotonin, and histamine to regulate gastric functions.

questions.text: Which of the following set of statements is true about familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)? It is autosomal recessive. If not treated, 100% of the cases progress to adenocarcinoma of the colon. Polyps do not arise after puberty. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation: 1. Familial adenomatous polyposis i. SMAD4 2. Juvenile polyposis ii. STK11 3. Tuberous sclerosis iii. APC gene 4. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome iv. TSC1
questions.explanation:
Genes mutation

Manifestations

MLH1, MSH2
  • Results in microsatellite instability
  • Causes cluster of cancer: Colorectal, Endometrial, Ovarian, Pancreatic cancers
  • Colon cancer develops at a young age, and it usually occurs on the right side.

SMAD4 and BMPR1

Juvenile polyposis syndrome

STK11

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

APC gene

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis(FAP), sporadic colon cancer, Gardner syndrome and Turcot syndrome

MUTYH

MUTYH-associated polyposis.

TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin)

Tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: Which of the following intestinal pathologies is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis?
questions.explanation:
Celiac Disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

It is influenced by HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8.

Pathogenesis

Clinical features

Adults:

  • Commonly between the ages of 30 and 60.
  • More frequent in females
  • Silent celiac disease (positive serology and villous atrophy without symptoms)
  • Latent celiac disease (positive serology is not accompanied by villous atrophy)
  • It may be associated with chronic diarrhoea, bloating, chronic fatigue, or asymptomatic.
  • Anaemia (iron and vitamin malabsorption).
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (itchy, blistering skin lesion) might be present. (Option C)

 

Pediatric cases:

  • Both sexes were affected equally.
  • It may present with malabsorption.
  • Begins after the introduction of gluten to the diet (6-24 months of age)
  • Manifestations include irritability, abdominal distention, anorexia, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, weight loss, or muscle wasting.
  • It may also present as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, or constipation.
  • Extraintestinal complaints include arthritis or joint pain, aphthous stomatitis, iron deficiency anaemia, delayed puberty, and short stature.

Serum markers
  • IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase (tTG): Most sensitive.
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Most specific.
  • IgG antibodies against gliadin (a component of gluten).

Histology

Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum:

  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis).
  • Crypt hyperplasia (Increased mitosis).
  • Villous atrophy (Reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption).
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration.

questions.text: Which of the following diet is not advised in celiac sprue disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Wh

Definition Celiac disease, also known as celiac sprue disease, is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, triggers an immune response that damages the lining of the small intestine.
Prevalence Celiac disease is relatively common, with a global prevalence estimated at around 1% of the population.
Symptoms - Gastrointestinal symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. - Non-gastrointestinal symptoms: Fatigue, anemia, dermatitis herpetiformis (skin rash), joint pain, and neurological symptoms.
Diagnosis - Blood tests: Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies, anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA), and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP) antibodies. - Small intestine biopsy: The gold standard for diagnosis, showing characteristic villous atrophy and inflammation. - Genetic testing: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 testing can be supportive but not diagnostic.
Treatment A strict gluten-free diet is the primary treatment for celiac disease. This involves avoiding all sources of gluten, including wheat, barley, and rye.
Complications - Malabsorption of nutrients: Celiac disease can lead to nutrient deficiencies, including iron, calcium, and vitamins. - Osteoporosis: Due to impaired calcium absorption. - Dermatitis herpetiformis: A chronic skin condition associated with celiac disease. - Increased risk of associated autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?

A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology, and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.explanation:
Features

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS)

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS)

Inheritance pattern

Autosomal dominant disorder

Autosomal dominant inheritance

Age

Presents around 11 years of age

Primarily affects children under 5 years old.

Features
  • Caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene 
  • Characterized by:
  • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
  • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Can be sporadic or syndromic.
  • Sporadic: Single polyps.
  • Syndromic: 3-100 polyps.
  • Linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.
  • Pedunculated polyp, which is usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • Extra-intestinal manifestations include congenital malformations and digital clubbing. 
Microscopy

An arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.

Contains cystic spaces filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

 

﻿Classification of Colorectal Polyps

Neoplastic Polyps

Non-Neoplastic Polyps

Adenomatous Polyps (Adenomas)

  • Tubular
  • Villous
  • Tubulovillous

Inflammatory Polyps

Associated with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

Serrated Polyps

  • Hyperplastic Polyps
  • Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA/Ps)
  • Traditional Serrated Adenomas (TSAs)

Hamartomatous Polyps

  • Juvenile Polyps: Usually in children, generally benign but associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome.
  • Peutz-Jeghers Polyps: Associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by pigmentation around the mouth.

-

Lymphoid Polyps

It is composed of lymphoid tissue, usually benign and associated with the immune response

questions.text: Which of the following can be given to a celiac disease patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Qu

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is present in celiac disease?
The distal ileum was removed from a 20-year-old girl. Which absorption deficiency will be seen?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Bile Intestine part resected Complications Duodenum

  • Delayed gastric emptying
  • Bile reflux gastritis
  • Malabsorption of iron
Jejunum
  • Malabsorption of various nutrients, including carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals
Ileum
  • Malabsorption of vitamin B12
  • Impaired reabsorption of bile salts
  • Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K)
Colon
  • Diarrhea (loose stools)
  • Increased water content in the stool
  • Electrolyte imbalances
  • Impaired absorption of water, sodium, and potassium

HSV esophagitis Shallow, well-demarcated ulcers with a punched-out appearance
CMV esophagitis Linear or linearly arranged shallow ulcers
Candida esophagitis Raised, white plaques or pseudomembranes
